{{About|the Comedian|the Australian rules footballer|Jesse Joyce (footballer)}} '''Jesse Joyce''' (born September 24, 1978) is an American [[stand-up comedian]],<ref>[http://themanfaq.com/jesse-joyces-jokes-deliver-for-himself-and-others/ "Jesse Joyce’s jokes deliver for himself and others"]. ''The Man FAQ'' by Tony Castleberry - Aug 30, 2013</ref> [[Emmy Award|Emmy Nominated]] and [[Writers Guild of America Award|WGA Award]] winning writer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://awards.wga.org/wga-awards/nominees-winners|title=2017 Writers Guild Awards Nominees & Winners|website=awards.wga.org|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref><ref name="emmys.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/bios/jesse-joyce|title=Jesse Joyce {{!}} Television Academy|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref><ref>[http://www.buffalonews.com/gusto/comedy/funny-business-is-a-way-of-life-for-jesse-joyce-20150114 "Funny business is a way of life for Jesse Joyce"]. ''Th Buffalo News''. By TIm O’Shei on January 14, 2015</ref><ref>[http://www.boweryboogie.com/2014/11/iron-sheik-roast-recap-didnt-know-wanted/ "The Iron Sheik Roast Recap You Didn’t Know You Wanted"]. ''Bowry Boogie''</ref> [[File:Jesse-Joyce-773470.jpg|thumb|Jesse Joyce]] Joyce has made many television appearances, including Comedy Central’s [[@midnight|@midnight with Chris Hardwick]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cc.com/shows/-midnight/guests/jesse-joyce/2qk79t/extended---uncovering-secret-government-programs---uncensored|title=Jesse Joyce - Extended - Uncovering Secret Government Programs - Uncensored - @midnight with Chris Hardwick Video Clip {{!}} Comedy Central|website=Comedy Central|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> Comedy Underground with [[Dave Attell]], ''[[Live At Gotham]]'', ''[[The Tonight Show With Jay Leno]]'', ''[[Last Call with Carson Daly]]'',<ref>{{Citation|title=Jesse Joyce|date=2015-11-03|url=https://www.nbc.com/last-call-with-carson-daly/video/jesse-joyce/2930387|accessdate=2018-03-19}}</ref> AXS’s Gotham Comedy Live, Comedy.TV, [[AMC (TV channel)|AMC]]’s ''Date Night'' , ''[[Comedy Central]]'s Roast Battle''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cc.com/video-clips/sb02ds/jeff-ross-presents-roast-battle-exclusive---road-to-roast-battle---jesse-joyce-vs--earl-skakel---uncensored|title=Exclusive - Road to Roast Battle - Jesse Joyce vs. Earl Skakel - Uncensored - Jeff Ross Presents Roast Battle (Video Clip) {{!}} Comedy Central|website=Comedy Central|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>'', Seeso's The Guest List''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ticketfly.com/event/1384786-guest-list-live-tv-taping-san-francisco/|title=The Guest List - Live TV Taping! Presented by Seeso and Audible, with KC Arora, Emmy Blotnick, Adam Cayton-Holland, Todd Glass and Jesse Joyce - Sunday 9:30pm - Tickets - The Chapel - San Francisco, CA - January 22nd, 2017|website=Ticketfly|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>and was a regular guest on [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]]’s ''I Love The 1880s'' and [[VH1]]’s ''Big Morning Buzz Live'' with [[Carrie Keagan]]. He was a recurring guest on ''[[Red Eye with Greg Gutfeld]]'' and was a semi-finalist on the 2010 season of [[Last Comic Standing]]. In addition he has written for numerous television specials and award shows, most notably the [[85th Academy Awards]], the [[90th Academy Awards]], and the [[Comedy Central Roasts]].
==Early life and education== Joyce was born in [[Pittsburgh, PA]]. He is a graduate of [[Bishop Canevin High School]] and [[Duquesne University]] in Pittsburgh with a dual major in Studio Art and Communication and a minor in Art History. While in high school he attended art classes at [[Carnegie Mellon University]]. He first took the stage as a comedian while working as a barback/janitor at The Pittsburgh Funnybone at the age of 18. Joyce continued to perform stand up comedy while attending Duquesne University in 1998.
==Career== After graduation, Joyce worked for a year as a designer and copywriter for Elisco Advertising in Pittsburgh; he won two [[ADDY Awards]] for his work.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} He took part in comedy in his spare time. He saved his money, and in 2001 he moved to [[New York City]].<ref>[http://www.dailyeasternnews.com/2008/09/15/comedian-jesse-joyce-packs-house-at-underground/ "Comedian Jesse Joyce packs house at Underground"]. Kristin Menas. ''Daily Eastern News'', September 15, 2008</ref>
Over the next few years he made several television appearances including Comedy Central’s Live at Gotham and hosting Date Night for AMC. In 2005 his manager paired him with another of his clients, [[Greg Giraldo]], since both had recently given up alcohol<ref name=c-r>[http://www.comedy-reviews.com/2011/01/jesse-joyce-joyce.html'"Jesse Joyce's "Pro Joyce"']. ''Comedy REviews''.</ref> and could support each other while working together.<ref name=McG>{{cite web|last=McGlynn|first=Katla|title='Give It Up For Greg Giraldo': Remembering A Legend|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/18/give-it-up-for-greg-giraldo_n_837772.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref> Joyce was Giraldo’s opening act and writing partner until Giraldo’s death in 2010. Together they wrote scripts for the many roasts which Giraldo performed, on including the Comedy Central Roasts of [[Flavor Flav]], [[Bob Saget]], [[Larry The Cable Guy]], [[Joan Rivers]], and [[David Hasselhoff]] and the TBS Celebrity Roast of [[Cheech and Chong]].<ref name=McG /> At the time of Giraldo’s death, the pair had begun working on the Cringe Humor Roast of [[Jim Florentine]], which Joyce performed in his place.<ref>{{cite web|last=Gadino|first=Dylan|title=Comedian friends joke about Greg Giraldo's death at roast|url=http://www.laughspin.com/2010/11/03/comedian-friends-joke-about-greg-giraldos-death-at-roast/|work=Laughspin.com|publisher=Laughspin|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207005227/http://www.laughspin.com/2010/11/03/comedian-friends-joke-about-greg-giraldos-death-at-roast/|archivedate=2012-02-07|df=}}</ref> He was then hired onto the staff for the Comedy Central Roasts of [[Donald Trump]], [[Charlie Sheen]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Hartsell|first=Carol|title=Charlie Sheen Roast: The Jokes You Didn't Hear|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/09/20/charlie-sheen-roast-jokes_n_972334.html|work=Huffington Post}}</ref> [[Roseanne]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Hartsell|first=Carol|title=Roseanne Roast: The Jokes You Didn't Hear|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/08/13/roseanne-roast-jokes-you-didnt-hear_n_1774020.html|work=Huffington Post|publisher=Huffington Post}}</ref> [[James Franco]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Hartsell|first=Carol|title=The Franco Roast Jokes You Didn't Hear: Comedian Jesse Joyce Tweets The Rejected Gags|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/04/franco-roast-jokes-you-didnt-hear_n_3867551.html|work=Huffington Post|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref> and [[Justin Bieber]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/03/31/justin-bieber-roast-jokes-jesse-joyce_n_6976584.html|title=The Justin Bieber Roast Jokes You Didn't Get To Hear|last=Comedy|first=Katla McGlynn Senior|last2=Editor|first2=Viral|date=2015-03-31|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-08-22|last3=Post|first3=The Huffington}}</ref> where he met and wrote for [[Seth MacFarlane]]. MacFarlane hired Joyce to write for him when he hosted the 85th Academy Awards.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hartsell|first=Carol|title=Rejected Oscars Jokes: Comedian Jesse Joyce Tweets The Jokes You Didn't Hear|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/25/rejected-oscars-jokes_n_2758305.html|work=Huffington Post}}</ref>
Joyce was a staff writer for the first two seasons of ''The Burn'' with [[Jeff Ross]] on [[Comedy Central]] . In addition to Giraldo, MacFarlane, and Ross, Joyce has also written jokes for [[Kevin Spacey]], [[Dave Attell]], [[Jim Norton (comedian)|Jim Norton]], [[Johnny Knoxville]], [[Jeff Dunham]], [[Triumph the Insult Comic Dog]] and the Today Show’s [[Matt Lauer]]. From 2014 through 2017 he was writer and regular guest on [[@midnight|@midnight with Chris Hardwick]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.comedymoontower.com/moontower-class-of-2016-jesse-joyce/|title=Moontower Class of 2016: Jesse Joyce {{!}}|website=www.comedymoontower.com|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> In 2016 Joyce was nominated for a [[Primetime Emmy Award|Primetime Emmy]] in the category of Outstanding Writing for A Variety Special<ref name="emmys.com"/> for [[Triumph, the Insult Comic Dog|Triumph]]'s 2016 Election Special on Hulu, for which he went on to win a 2017 [[Writers Guild of America Award|Writers' Guild Award]] for Best Comedy/Variety Special.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://awards.wga.org/wga-awards/nominees-winners|title=2017 Writers Guild Awards Nominees & Winners|website=awards.wga.org|access-date=2017-02-23}}</ref> Since 2017 Jesse has been a writer for [[Jimmy Kimmel Live!|Jimmy Kimmel Live]] on [[ABC Studios|ABC]] and was nominated for a 2018 [[Writers Guild of America Award|Writer's Guild Award]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://awards.wga.org/wga-awards/nominees-winners|title=2018 Writers Guild Awards Nominees and Winners|website=awards.wga.org|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref>for Best Comedy/Variety Series.
In 2008 Joyce performed for American Service Men and Women in Iraq, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Djibouti in East Africa. He has also performed internationally in Switzerland, Ireland, China, Malaysia, Singapore and was invited to perform at the [[Just For Laughs]] Comedy Festival in 2013 in Montreal Canada.
In 2009 Joyce was chosen for the role of Price in the independent film [[Stags]] produced by [[Ben Barenholtz]]. In 2010 he was a semi-finalist on NBC’s Last Comic Standing finishing in the top 20.<ref>[http://montrealgazette.com/entertainment/comedy-picks-sept-9-14-sebastien-bourgault-jesse-joyce-paul-ash "Comedy Picks: Sept. 9 – 14 – Sébastien Bourgault, Jesse Joyce, Paul Ash"]. Bill Brownstein, ''Montreal Gazette'', September 9, 2013</ref> He has been a regular guest on the [[Fox News]] late night comedy program ''[[Red Eye w/Greg Gutfeld]]'' since 2009. Joyce has released two albums, the first, ''Joyce To The World'' was released independently in 2005 and his sophomore album ''Pro Joyce'' was released through Rooftop Records in 2011.<ref name=c-r />
==Personal life==
Joyce is a recovering alcoholic who has been sober since June 5, 2005 and often performs at rehabilitation and recovery centers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Jesse Joyce: He is Doing Exactly What He Said He would do When He was 11. Can You Say That?|url=http://recoverycomedy.livejournal.com/8694.html|work=RecoveryComedy.com|publisher=Recovery Comedy|accessdate=23 October 2013}}</ref> In 2010, he married Haley Kozlowski, but the couple divorced in 2012. In 2015, he married Emily Cook.
